reviewText: Most fans are wondering just what tinkering Lucas did with his first film. I know when I first heard he was giving it a "special edition" style makeover, two shots immediately came to mind: the ridiculous, ordinary modern doorknob with keyhole that the robots are trying to circumvent, and a shot where the futuristic race car THX has stolen clearly sports "Firestone" brand tires.Well, much to my surprise, both of those shots survived into this new special edition! So what got changed? There's good news and bad.The world itself is enlarged with new backgrounds and expanded vistas, not unlike some of the tinkering we saw with Cloud City in the Empire Strikes Back Special Edition. What were once dead ends or nondescript tunnels have morphed into busy elevator shafts and shuttle buses. Overall the effect is good, although sometimes the added effects seem too busy compared to the main action.New creatures! A pack of bizarre monkeys now attacks our hero instead of the little-people shell dwellers. It actually comes off better than it might sound. Also added are a bizarre scorpion creature that frightens SEN, and a lizard stuck in the computer works seems to have sprouted antenna and wings(?)The robot factory where THX works is much larger and busier. Now when THX is urged to "make the correction" we see exactly what that correction entails as a new radioactive rod melts everything in its path as it rolls around on the work table. Also the danger involved is more evident as we see people engulfed in explosions.Most shocking addition? How about what I could only describe as a "mastrubation machine" pumping away as THX is watching his hologram television. Kind of creepy but definitely a ballsy move...no pun intended.Finally the big car chase at the end has been enhanced with a few barricades here and there. But the main change is an additional passage which has him driving like a mad man through the rush hour traffic. The segment is exciting and looks good, but it doesn't really transition well with the original footage, and the frantic action and camera movement does not match the tone of the original footage. Also, in this new footage, THX seems to be driving the car like a professional racer, as opposed to the rest of the footage where he seems like he can barely keep the thing in a straight line.It is a jarring addition, but not a disaster.One major misstep with this DVD release is not a single mention is made of these digital enhancements in any of the supplementary material. Its as if Lucas wants to just rewrite history and pretend this is how the movie always looked. If he wants to bury the original version, fine, that's his decision, but at least let his fans in on his decision making process in making these changes and how they were technically achieved!

reviewText: I remembered this as a good movie. I was wrong - it's a great movie.Most of the movie is set against a blank, whiteout background; even the uniforms and uniformly shaved heads turn people into blanks. Oddly, that makes each little spot, wrinkle, or bump on an actor that much more visible, distinctive, and even attractive. Most of the movie is set in a drug-dazed vapidity. When THX (our hero) shakes off the tranquilizer, the world changes into something claustrophobic and incomprehensible. Again and again, Lucas uses imagery to create a "Brave New World" dystopia. It seems to turn people into machines, like the robot "officers" that enforce that world's laws. Lucas goes beyond irony into chilling prophecy when he shows how often those machines malfunction.Above all, there is no human voice. There are staticky transmissions of orders and robotic commands. There are environmental sounds and warning signals. There just isn't any spoken word. Lucas' characters literally have no voice.This 1971 movie is a creature of its time. The pervasive video screens have those traveling bands of bright and dark, giving them a somewhat antiquated look. Nixie tubes are now sought after for their retro look, and even the technology for making htem has been forgotten. And the computers - well, have you  actually seen a reel to reel computer tape? Also, the crime of "drug evasion" probably had different meaning at the end of the 1960s, a symbol of a world turned upside down.This was Lucas's first big film, and one that he never forgot. When you see American Graffiti, check the license plate on that big yellow car. When you see Star Wars, where Luke, Han, and Chewie enter the prison to rescue Leia, note where they came from.First, however, see this movie. Although it sometimes lacks in subtlety, it lacks nothing in dystopian imact.//wiredweird

reviewText: Expanded plot and scrutinous character development are advantages gained in this project spawned from Lucas's notorious Senior Project. Although we're never given time-frame or civilization reference, we're shown a society arrested through high technology by a "tour guide" named THX 1138 ("Thex") who finds that his homogenized and severely regulated existence is in conflict with instinctive biological drives although he cannot pinpoint his discomfort any more than his synthetic father-confessor-diety can. His mate LUH, also shares his anguish while a close associate in Computer Control tries manipulating their existence to meet his own selfish ends. 1138 eventually reaches a point in isolation when he finally decides to escape his sterile lifestyle in favor of crossing forbidden boundaries to see what lies beyond. Thanks to Coppola's insistence that Lucas be more intense in scriptwriting, we are given a more comprehensive view of what he may have obscured in his first effort. This will probably go down as one of Robert Duvall's career best to date; but to all intents and purposes, it is an acquired taste at best.
